# US Airways Flight 1549

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

**US Airways Flight 1549** was an [Airbus A320-214](/wiki/Airbus_A320-214
"Airbus A320-214") which, in the [climbout](/wiki/Climb_\(aeronautics\) "Climb
\(aeronautics\)") after takeoff from New York City's [LaGuardia
Airport](/wiki/LaGuardia_Airport "LaGuardia Airport") on January 15, 2009,
[struck a flock](/wiki/Bird_strikes "Bird strikes") of [Canada
geese](/wiki/Canada_geese "Canada geese") just northeast of the [George
Washington Bridge](/wiki/George_Washington_Bridge "George Washington Bridge")
and consequently lost all [engine](/wiki/Jet_engine "Jet engine") power.
Unable to reach any airport, pilots [Chesley
Sullenberger](/wiki/Chesley_Sullenberger "Chesley Sullenberger") and Jeffrey
Skiles glided the plane to a [ditching](/wiki/Ditching "Ditching") in the
[Hudson River](/wiki/Hudson_River "Hudson River") off [Midtown
Manhattan](/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan "Midtown Manhattan"). All 155 people aboard
were rescued by nearby boats and there were few serious injuries.

The accident came to be known as the "**Miracle on the Hudson** ",[4][5][6]
and a [National Transportation Safety
Board](/wiki/National_Transportation_Safety_Board "National Transportation
Safety Board") official described it as "the most successful ditching in
aviation history."[7] The Board rejected the notion that the pilot could have
avoided ditching by returning to LaGuardia or diverting to nearby [Teterboro
Airport](/wiki/Teterboro_Airport "Teterboro Airport").

The pilots and flight attendants were awarded the Master's Medal of the [Guild
of Air Pilots and Air Navigators](/wiki/Guild_of_Air_Pilots_and_Air_Navigators
"Guild of Air Pilots and Air Navigators") in recognition of their "heroic and
unique aviation achievement".[8]

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=US_Airways_Flight_1549&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Airbus_A320-214%2C_US_Airways_Shuttle_AN0205775.jpg/220px-
Airbus_A320-214%2C_US_Airways_Shuttle_AN0205775.jpg)](/wiki/File:Airbus_A320-214,_US_Airways_Shuttle_AN0205775.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Airbus_A320-214,_US_Airways_Shuttle_AN0205775.jpg "Enlarge")

N106US at LaGuardia in 2001

On January 15, 2009, US Airways Flight 1549[b] with [call
sign](/wiki/Aviation_call_signs "Aviation call signs") 'CACTUS 1549' was
scheduled to fly from New York City's LaGuardia Airport (LGA) to [Charlotte
Douglas (CLT)](/wiki/Charlotte_Douglas_International_Airport "Charlotte
Douglas International Airport"), with [direct onward
service](/wiki/Direct_flight "Direct flight") to [Seattle–Tacoma International
Airport](/wiki/Seattle%E2%80%93Tacoma_International_Airport "Seattle–Tacoma
International Airport"). The aircraft was an [Airbus
A320-214](/wiki/Airbus_A320-214 "Airbus A320-214") powered by two [GE
Aviation](/wiki/GE_Aviation "GE Aviation")/[Snecma](/wiki/Snecma
"Snecma")-designed [CFM56-5B4/P](/wiki/CFM_International_CFM56 "CFM
International CFM56") [turbofan](/wiki/Turbofan "Turbofan") engines.[9][c]

The [pilot in command](/wiki/Pilot_in_command "Pilot in command") was 57-year-
old [Chesley B. "Sully" Sullenberger](/wiki/Chesley_Sullenberger "Chesley
Sullenberger"), a former fighter pilot who had been an airline pilot since
leaving the [United States Air Force](/wiki/United_States_Air_Force "United
States Air Force") in 1980. At the time, he had logged 19,663 total flight
hours, including 4,765 in an A320; he was also a
[glider](/wiki/Glider_\(sailplane\) "Glider \(sailplane\)") pilot and expert
on [aviation safety](/wiki/Aviation_safety "Aviation safety").[12][13][14]
[First officer](/wiki/First_officer_\(aeronautics\) "First officer
\(aeronautics\)") Jeffrey B. Skiles, 49,[13][15][16] had accrued 15,643 career
flight hours, but this was his first Airbus A320 assignment since qualifying
to fly it.[17] There were 150 passengers and three [flight
attendants](/wiki/Flight_attendant "Flight attendant") aboard.[1][18]

##
Accident[[edit](/w/index.php?title=US_Airways_Flight_1549&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Accident")]

### Takeoff and bird
strike[[edit](/w/index.php?title=US_Airways_Flight_1549&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Takeoff and bird strike")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/LGA_RWY_4_DEP_15JAN2009.jpg/180px-
LGA_RWY_4_DEP_15JAN2009.jpg)](/wiki/File:LGA_RWY_4_DEP_15JAN2009.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:LGA_RWY_4_DEP_15JAN2009.jpg "Enlarge")

LaGuardia Runway 4 departure.

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png) |  [New York TRACON audio](/wiki/File:Flight_1549_FAA_New_York_TRACON_audio_extract.ogg "File:Flight 1549 FAA New York TRACON audio extract.ogg") ![](data:image/png,%89PNG%0D%0A%1A%0A%00%00%00%0DIHDR%00%00%00%01%00%00%00%01%08%02%00%00%00%90wS%DE%00%00%00%01sRGB%00%AE%CE%1C%E9%00%00%00%09pHYs%00%00%0B%13%00%00%0B%13%01%00%9A%9C%18%00%00%00%07tIME%07%DB%0B%0A%17%041%80%9B%E7%F2%00%00%00%19tEXtComment%00Created%20with%20GIMPW%81%0E%17%00%00%00%0CIDAT%08%D7c%60%60%60%00%00%00%04%00%01'4'%0A%00%00%00%00IEND%AEB%60%82)[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b5/Flight_1549_FAA_New_York_TRACON_audio_extract.ogg) Air traffic control audio from about time of bird strike until ditching (3:10 long)  
---|---  
  
* * *

_Problems playing this file? See[media help](/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help
"Wikipedia:Media help")._  
  
The flight was cleared for takeoff to the northeast from LaGuardia's Runway 4
at 3:24:56 pm Eastern Standard Time (20:24:56 UTC). With Skiles in control,
the crew made its first report after becoming airborne at 3:25:51 as being at
700 feet (210 m) and climbing.[19]

The weather at 2:51 p.m. was 10 miles (16 km) visibility with
[broken](/wiki/Okta "Okta") clouds at 3,700 feet (1,100 m), wind 8 knots (15
km/h; 9.2 mph) from 290°; an hour later it was [few](/wiki/Okta "Okta") clouds
at 4,200 feet (1,300 m), wind 9 knots (17 km/h; 10 mph) from 310°.[20] At
3:26:37 Sullenberger remarked to Skiles: "What a view of the Hudson
today."[21]

[![The aircraft headed approximately north after takeoff, then wheeled anti-
clockwise to follow the Hudson
southwards.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Flight_1549-OptionsNotTaken.PNG/400px-
Flight_1549-OptionsNotTaken.PNG)](/wiki/File:Flight_1549-OptionsNotTaken.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:Flight_1549-OptionsNotTaken.PNG "Enlarge")

Flight path flown (red). Alternative trajectories to Teterboro (blue) and back
toward La Guardia (purple) were simulated for the investigation.

At 3:27:11 the plane struck a flock of [Canada geese](/wiki/Canada_geese
"Canada geese") at an altitude of 2,818 feet (859 m) about 4.5 miles (7.2 km)
north-northwest of LaGuardia. The pilots' view was filled with the large
birds;[22][23] passengers and crew heard very loud bangs and saw flames from
the engines, followed by silence and an odor of [fuel](/wiki/Jet_fuel "Jet
fuel").[24][25][26]

Realizing that both engines had shut down, Sullenberger took control while
Skiles worked the checklist for engine restart.[d][2] The aircraft slowed but
continued to climb for a further 19 seconds, reaching about 3,060 feet (930 m)
at an airspeed of about 185 knots (343 km/h; 213 mph), then began a glide
descent, accelerating to 210 knots (390 km/h; 240 mph) at 3:28:10 as it
descended through 1,650 feet (500 m).

At 3:27:33, Sullenberger radioed a mayday call to [New York Terminal Radar
Approach Control (TRACON)](/wiki/New_York_TRACON "New York TRACON"):[28][29]
"... this is Cactus 1539 [sic – correct [call sign](/wiki/Call_sign#Aviation
"Call sign") was Cactus 1549], hit birds. We've lost thrust on both engines.
We're turning back towards LaGuardia".[21] [Air traffic](/wiki/New_York_TRACON
"New York TRACON") controller Patrick Harten[30] told LaGuardia's
[tower](/wiki/Air_traffic_control#Local_control_or_air_control "Air traffic
control") to hold all departures, and directed Sullenberger back to Runway
13.[29] Sullenberger responded, "Unable".[29]

Sullenberger asked controllers for landing options in [New
Jersey](/wiki/New_Jersey "New Jersey"), mentioning [Teterboro
Airport](/wiki/Teterboro_Airport "Teterboro Airport").[29][31][32] Permission
was given for Teterboro's Runway 1,[32] but Sullenberger responded: "We can't
do it ... We're gonna be in the Hudson".[31] The aircraft passed less than 900
feet (270 m) above the [George Washington
Bridge](/wiki/George_Washington_Bridge "George Washington Bridge").[33]
Sullenberger commanded over the cabin address system, "[Brace for
impact](/wiki/Brace_position "Brace position")",[33] and the flight attendants
relayed the command to passengers.[34] Meanwhile, air traffic controllers
asked the [Coast Guard](/wiki/United_States_Coast_Guard "United States Coast
Guard") to caution vessels in the Hudson and ask them to prepare to assist
with rescue.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Ditching and
evacuation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=US_Airways_Flight_1549&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Ditching and evacuation")]

![File:Flight1549CrashAndRescue.ogv](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Flight1549CrashAndRescue.ogv/220px-
seek%3D50-Flight1549CrashAndRescue.ogv.jpg)[Play
media](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/67/Flight1549CrashAndRescue.ogv
"Play media")

[](/wiki/File:Flight1549CrashAndRescue.ogv "Enlarge")

[Coast Guard](/wiki/United_States_Coast_Guard "United States Coast Guard")
video of crash and rescue.

About ninety seconds later, at 3:31 pm, the plane made an
[unpowered](/wiki/Deadstick_landing "Deadstick landing") ditching, descending
southwards at about 125 knots (140 mph; 230 km/h) into the middle of the
[North River](/wiki/North_River_\(New_York-New_Jersey\) "North River \(New
York-New Jersey\)") section of the Hudson tidal [estuary](/wiki/Estuary
"Estuary"), at [40°46′10″N 74°00′17″W﻿ / ﻿40.7695°N 74.0046°W﻿ / 40.7695;
-74.0046](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=US_Airways_Flight_1549&params=40.7695_N_74.0046_W_region:US-
NY_type:event)[35] on the [New York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\) "New York
\(state\)") side of the state line, roughly opposite West 50th Street (near
the [Intrepid Sea, Air & Space
Museum](/wiki/Intrepid_Sea,_Air_%26_Space_Museum "Intrepid Sea, Air & Space
Museum")) in [Manhattan](/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan") and [Port
Imperial](/wiki/Port_Imperial "Port Imperial") in [Weehawken, New
Jersey](/wiki/Weehawken,_New_Jersey "Weehawken, New Jersey"). Flight
attendants compared the ditching to a "hard landing" with "one impact, no
bounce, then a gradual deceleration."[31] The [ebb
tide](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ebb_tide "wikt:ebb tide") then began to
take the plane southward.[36]

Sullenberger opened the cockpit door and ordered evacuation. The crew began
evacuating the passengers through the four overwing window exits and into an
inflatable [slide](/wiki/Evacuation_slide "Evacuation slide")/raft deployed
from the front right passenger door (the front left slide failed to operate,
so the manual inflation handle was pulled). A panicked passenger opened a rear
door, which a flight attendant was unable to reseal.[37] Water was also
entering a hole in the fuselage and through cargo doors that had come
open,[38] so as the water rose the attendant urged passengers to move forward
by climbing over seats.[e] One passenger was in a wheelchair.[40][41] Finally,
Sullenberger walked the cabin twice to confirm it was empty.[42][43][44]

![File:Flight1549After20Minutes.ogv](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Flight1549After20Minutes.ogv/220px-
seek%3D0-Flight1549After20Minutes.ogv.jpg)[Play
media](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b3/Flight1549After20Minutes.ogv
"Play media")

[](/wiki/File:Flight1549After20Minutes.ogv "Enlarge")

Video beginning 20 minutes after ditching, with numerous ferries and rescue
boats surrounding the aircraft.

The air and water temperatures were about 19 °F (−7 °C) and 41 °F (5 °C)
respectively.[20] Some evacuees waited for rescue knee-deep in water on the
partially submerged slides, some wearing life-vests. Others stood on the wings
or, fearing an explosion, swam away from the plane.[37] One passenger, after
helping with the evacuation, found the wing so crowded that he jumped into the
river and swam to a boat.[45][31][46]

###
Rescue[[edit](/w/index.php?title=US_Airways_Flight_1549&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Rescue")]

Sullenberger had ditched near boats which facilitated rescue.[19][42] [NY
Waterway](/wiki/NY_Waterway "NY Waterway") ferries _Thomas Jefferson_ and then
_Governor Thomas H. Kean_ both arrived within minutes[47][48] and began taking
people aboard using a [Jason's cradle](/wiki/Jason%27s_cradle "Jason's
cradle"). Sullenberger advised the ferry crews to rescue those on the wings
first, as they were in more jeopardy than those on the slides, which detached
to become [life rafts](/wiki/Life_raft "Life raft").[33] As the plane drifted,
passengers on one slide, fearing that the boat would crush them, shouted for
it to steer away.[49] The last person was taken from the plane at 3:55 pm.[50]

About 140 New York City firefighters responded to nearby docks,[51][52][53] as
did police, helicopters, and various vessels and divers.[51] Other agencies
provided medical help on the [Weehawken](/wiki/Weehawken,_New_Jersey
"Weehawken, New Jersey") side of the river, where most passengers were
taken.[54]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/US_Airways_Flight_1549_in_Hudson_cropped.JPG/770px-
US_Airways_Flight_1549_in_Hudson_cropped.JPG)](/wiki/File:US_Airways_Flight_1549_in_Hudson_cropped.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:US_Airways_Flight_1549_in_Hudson_cropped.JPG "Enlarge")

The half-sunken plane surrounded by boats.

##
Aftermath[[edit](/w/index.php?title=US_Airways_Flight_1549&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Aftermath")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Flight1549BatteryPark2_crop.jpg/220px-
Flight1549BatteryPark2_crop.jpg)](/wiki/File:Flight1549BatteryPark2_crop.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Flight1549BatteryPark2_crop.jpg "Enlarge")

The aircraft tied up alongside [Battery Park City](/wiki/Battery_Park_City
"Battery Park City").

There were five serious injuries,[2] including a deep
[laceration](/wiki/Laceration "Laceration") in [flight
attendant](/wiki/Flight_attendant "Flight attendant") Doreen Welsh's
leg.[31][55] Seventy-eight people were treated, mostly for minor injuries[56]
and [hypothermia](/wiki/Hypothermia "Hypothermia"),[57] twenty-four passengers
and two rescuers treated at hospitals,[58] with two passengers kept overnight.
One passenger now wears glasses because of jet fuel damaging his eyes.[45] No
pets were being carried on the flight.[59]

Each passenger later received a letter of apology, $5,000 in compensation for
lost baggage (and $5,000 more if they could demonstrate larger losses) and
refund of the ticket price.[60][61] In May 2009 they received any belongings
that had been recovered. In addition, they reported offers of $10,000 each in
return for [agreeing not to sue](/wiki/Settlement_\(litigation\) "Settlement
\(litigation\)") US Airways.[62]

Many passengers and rescuers later experienced [post-traumatic
stress](/wiki/Post-traumatic_stress "Post-traumatic stress") symptoms such as
sleeplessness, [flashbacks](/wiki/Flashback_\(psychology\) "Flashback
\(psychology\)"), and [panic attacks](/wiki/Panic_attacks "Panic attacks");
some began an email [support group](/wiki/Support_group "Support group").[63]
Patrick Harten, the controller who had worked the flight, said that "the
hardest, most traumatic part of the entire event was when it was over", and
that he was "gripped by raw moments of shock and grief".[64]

In an effort to prevent similar accidents, officials captured and
[gassed](/wiki/Animal_euthanasia "Animal euthanasia") 1,235 Canada geese at 17
locations across New York City in mid-2009 and [coated 1,739 goose eggs with
oil to smother the developing goslings](/wiki/Goose_egg_addling "Goose egg
addling").[65]

##
Investigation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=US_Airways_Flight_1549&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Investigation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/USAirways-1549_lifting_out_of_Hudson.jpg/170px-
USAirways-1549_lifting_out_of_Hudson.jpg)](/wiki/File:USAirways-1549_lifting_out_of_Hudson.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:USAirways-1549_lifting_out_of_Hudson.jpg "Enlarge")

The plane being recovered from the river during the night of January 17.

The partially submerged plane was moored to a pier near the [World Financial
Center](/wiki/Brookfield_Place_\(New_York_City\) "Brookfield Place \(New York
City\)") in [Lower Manhattan](/wiki/Lower_Manhattan "Lower Manhattan"),
roughly 4 miles (6 km) downstream from the ditching location.[34] The left
engine, detached by the ditching, was recovered from the riverbed.[66] On
January 17 the aircraft was barged[67][68] to New Jersey.[69]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/USAir_1549_bird_feather.jpg/170px-
USAir_1549_bird_feather.jpg)](/wiki/File:USAir_1549_bird_feather.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:USAir_1549_bird_feather.jpg "Enlarge")

Feather found in left engine.

The initial [National Transportation Safety
Board](/wiki/National_Transportation_Safety_Board "National Transportation
Safety Board") (NTSB) evaluation that the plane had lost thrust after a bird
strike[70][71][72] was confirmed by analysis of the [cockpit
voice](/wiki/Cockpit_voice_recorder "Cockpit voice recorder") and [flight data
recorders](/wiki/Flight_data_recorder "Flight data recorder").[73]

Two days earlier the plane had experienced a less severe [compressor
stall](/wiki/Compressor_stall "Compressor stall"),[74][75] but the affected
engine was restarted. A faulty temperature sensor was replaced, and inspection
verified the engine had not been damaged in that incident.[76]

On January 21, the NTSB found evidence of soft-body damage in the right engine
along with organic debris including a feather.[77][78] The left engine also
evidenced soft body impact, with: "dents on both the spinner and inlet lip of
the engine cowling. Five booster inlet guide vanes are fractured and eight
outlet guide vanes are missing." Both engines, missing large portions of their
housings,[79] were sent to the manufacturer for examination.[80] On January
31, the plane was moved to [Kearny, New Jersey](/wiki/Kearny,_New_Jersey
"Kearny, New Jersey"). The bird remains[76][81] were later identified by
[DNA](/wiki/DNA "DNA") testing to be [Canada geese](/wiki/Canada_geese "Canada
geese"), which typically weigh more than engines are designed to withstand
ingesting.[76]

Because the plane was assembled in France[82] the [European Aviation Safety
Agency](/wiki/European_Aviation_Safety_Agency "European Aviation Safety
Agency") (the European counterpart of the FAA) and the [Bureau d'Enquêtes et
d'Analyses pour la Sécurité de l'Aviation
Civile](/wiki/Bureau_d%27Enqu%C3%AAtes_et_d%27Analyses_pour_la_S%C3%A9curit%C3%A9_de_l%27Aviation_Civile
"Bureau d'Enquêtes et d'Analyses pour la Sécurité de l'Aviation Civile") (the
French counterpart of the NTSB) joined the investigation, with technical
assistance from Airbus Industrie and GE Aviation/Snecma, respectively the
manufacturers of the airframe and the engines.[83][84]

The NTSB used [flight simulators](/wiki/Flight_simulators "Flight simulators")
to test the possibility that the flight could have returned safely to
LaGuardia or diverted to Teterboro; only seven of the thirteen simulated
returns to La Guardia succeeded, and only one of the two to Teterboro.[85]
Furthermore, the NTSB report called these simulations unrealistic: "The
immediate turn made by the pilots during the simulations did not reflect or
account for real-world considerations." A further simulation, conducted with
the pilot delayed by 35 seconds, crashed.[86] In testimony before the NTSB,
Sullenberger maintained that there had been no time to bring the plane to any
airport, and that attempting to do so would likely have killed those onboard
and more on the ground.[87]

The Board ultimately ruled that Sullenberger had made the correct
decision,[87] reasoning that the checklist for dual-engine failure is designed
for higher altitudes, when pilots have more time to deal with the situation,
and that while simulations showed that the plane might have just barely made
it back to LaGuardia, those scenarios assumed an instant decision to do so,
with no time allowed for assessing the situation.[88][89]

The NTSB concluded its investigation on May 4, 2010, identifying the probable
cause as "the ingestion of large birds into each engine, which resulted in an
almost total loss of thrust in both engines."[86] The final report credited
the outcome to four factors: good decision-making and teamwork by the cockpit
crew (including decisions to immediately turn on the
[APU](/wiki/Auxiliary_power_unit "Auxiliary power unit") and to ditch in the
Hudson); the fact that the A320 is [certified for extended overwater
operation](/wiki/ETOPS "ETOPS") (and hence carried life vests and additional
raft/slides) even though not required for that route; the performance of the
flight crew during the evacuation; and the proximity of working vessels to the
ditching site. Contributing factors were good visibility and a fast response
from the ferry operators and emergency responders. The report also makes a
range of recommendations to improve safety in such situations.[2]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/N106US_aviation_museum.jpg/220px-N106US_aviation_museum.jpg)](/wiki/File:N106US_aviation_museum.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:N106US_aviation_museum.jpg "Enlarge")

N106US on display at [Carolinas Aviation
Museum](/wiki/Carolinas_Aviation_Museum "Carolinas Aviation Museum").

Author and pilot [William Langewiesche](/wiki/William_Langewiesche "William
Langewiesche") asserted that insufficient credit was given to the A320's [fly-
by-wire](/wiki/Fly-by-wire "Fly-by-wire") design, by which the pilot uses a
[side-stick](/wiki/Side-stick "Side-stick") to make control inputs to the
flight control computers. The computers then impose adjustments and limits of
their own to keep the plane stable, which the pilot cannot override even in an
emergency. This design allowed the pilots of Flight 1549 to concentrate on
engine restart and deciding the course, without the burden of manually
adjusting the glidepath to reduce the plane's rate of descent.[50]
Sullenberger said that these computer-imposed limits also prevented him from
achieving the optimum [landing flare](/wiki/Landing_flare "Landing flare") for
the ditching, which would have softened the impact.[90]

In 2010, the damaged plane (excluding its engines)[91] was acquired for the
[Carolinas Aviation Museum](/wiki/Carolinas_Aviation_Museum "Carolinas
Aviation Museum") in [Charlotte, North
Carolina](/wiki/Charlotte,_North_Carolina "Charlotte, North Carolina"),[92]
which held a reception on June 11 to commemorate the arrival in Charlotte of
the plane's body, with Sullenberger as keynote speaker and the passengers
invited.[93][94][95][96]

## Crew awards and
honors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=US_Airways_Flight_1549&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Crew awards and honors")]

The reactions of all members of the crew, the split second decision making and
the handling of this emergency and evacuation was "text book" and an example
to us all. To have safely executed this emergency ditching and evacuation,
with the loss of no lives, is a heroic and unique aviation achievement.

—Guild of Air Pilots and Air Navigators citation

An NTSB board member called the ditching "the most successful ... in aviation
history. These people knew what they were supposed to do and they did it and
as a result, no lives were lost."[97]

The crew, especially Sullenberger, was praised, notably by New York City Mayor
[Michael Bloomberg](/wiki/Michael_Bloomberg "Michael Bloomberg") and New York
State Governor [David Paterson](/wiki/David_Paterson "David Paterson"), who
said: "We had a _[Miracle on 34th Street](/wiki/Miracle_on_34th_Street
"Miracle on 34th Street")._ I believe now we have had a Miracle on the
Hudson."[56][98][99] [U.S. President](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States
"President of the United States") [George W. Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush
"George W. Bush") said he was "inspired by the skill and heroism of the flight
crew," and praised the emergency responders and volunteers.[100] [President-
elect](/wiki/President-elect_of_the_United_States "President-elect of the
United States") [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama") said that
everyone was proud of Sullenberger's "heroic and graceful job in landing the
damaged aircraft." He thanked the crew, whom he invited to [his
inauguration](/wiki/Barack_Obama_2009_presidential_inauguration "Barack Obama
2009 presidential inauguration") five days later.[101][102]

The [Guild of Air Pilots and Air
Navigators](/wiki/Guild_of_Air_Pilots_and_Air_Navigators "Guild of Air Pilots
and Air Navigators") awarded the crew a Master's Medal on January 22, 2009;
this is awarded only rarely, for outstanding aviation achievements at the
discretion of the Master of the Guild.[8] New York City Mayor [Michael
Bloomberg](/wiki/Michael_Bloomberg "Michael Bloomberg") presented the crew
with the [Keys to the City](/wiki/Freedom_of_the_City#Key_to_the_City "Freedom
of the City"), and Sullenberger with a replacement copy of a library book lost
on the flight, Sidney Dekker's _Just Culture: Balancing Safety and
Accountability_.[103] Rescuers received Certificates of Honor.[104]

The crew received a standing ovation at the [Super Bowl
XLIII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLIII "Super Bowl XLIII") on February 1, 2009,[105]
and Sullenberger threw out the [first pitch](/wiki/First_Pitch "First Pitch")
at the 2009 [Major League Baseball](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball "Major League
Baseball") season for the [San Francisco Giants](/wiki/San_Francisco_Giants
"San Francisco Giants"). His Giants' jersey was inscribed with the name
"Sully" and the number 155 – the count of people aboard the plane.[106]

On July 28, passengers Dave Sanderson and Barry Leonard organized a thank you
luncheon for emergency responders from [Hudson County, New
Jersey](/wiki/Hudson_County,_New_Jersey "Hudson County, New Jersey"), on the
shores of [Palisades Medical Center](/wiki/Palisades_Medical_Center "Palisades
Medical Center") in [North Bergen, New Jersey](/wiki/North_Bergen,_New_Jersey
"North Bergen, New Jersey"), where 57 passengers had been brought following
their rescue. Present were members of the [U.S. Coast
Guard](/wiki/U.S._Coast_Guard "U.S. Coast Guard"), [North Hudson Regional Fire
and Rescue](/wiki/North_Hudson_Regional_Fire_and_Rescue "North Hudson Regional
Fire and Rescue"), NY Waterway Ferries, the [American Red
Cross](/wiki/American_Red_Cross "American Red Cross"),
[Weehawken](/wiki/Weehawken,_New_Jersey "Weehawken, New Jersey") Volunteer
First Aid, the Weehawken Police Department, [West New
York](/wiki/West_New_York,_New_Jersey "West New York, New Jersey") E.M.S.,
North Bergen E.M.S., the Hudson County Office of Emergency Management, the New
Jersey E.M.S. Task Force, the [Guttenberg](/wiki/Guttenberg,_New_Jersey
"Guttenberg, New Jersey") Police Department, McCabe Ambulance, the
[Harrison](/wiki/Harrison,_New_Jersey "Harrison, New Jersey") Police
Department, and doctors and nurses who treated survivors.[107][108]

Sullenberger was named [Grand
Marshal](/wiki/Grand_Marshals_of_the_Tournament_of_Roses_Parade "Grand
Marshals of the Tournament of Roses Parade") for the 2010 [Tournament of Roses
Parade](/wiki/Rose_Parade "Rose Parade") in [Pasadena,
California](/wiki/Pasadena,_California "Pasadena, California").

In August 2010, [Jeppesen](/wiki/Jeppesen "Jeppesen") issued an [approach
plate](/wiki/Approach_plate "Approach plate") titled "Hudson Miracle APCH,"
dedicated to the five crew of Flight 1549 and annotated "Presented with Pride
and Gratitude from your friends at Jeppesen."[109]

Sullenberger retired on March 3, 2010, after thirty years with US Airways and
its predecessor, [Pacific Southwest Airlines](/wiki/Pacific_Southwest_Airlines
"Pacific Southwest Airlines"). At the end of his final flight he was reunited
with Skiles and a number of the passengers from Flight 1549.[110]

## Media and popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=US_Airways_Flight_1549&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Media and popular culture")]

The accident was recorded by several [closed-circuit television](/wiki/Closed-
circuit_television "Closed-circuit television") cameras. Various television
reports and documentaries produced soon afterwards contained extensive video
of the ditching and rescue, and recorded interviews with the aircrew,
passengers, rescuers, and other key participants. These included:

  * On February 8, 2009, the [CBS](/wiki/CBS "CBS") program _[60 Minutes](/wiki/60_Minutes "60 Minutes")_ broadcast three segments that included interviews with the aircrew as well as their reunion with passengers. The program aired again on July 5, 2009. 
    * "Flight 1549: A Routine Takeoff Turns Ugly"[111]
    * "Flight 1549: Saving 155 Souls In Minutes"[112]
    * "Flight 1549: An Emotional Reunion"[113]
  * On February 19, 2009, [Channel 4](/wiki/Channel_4 "Channel 4") in the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") aired a documentary entitled _The Miracle of the Hudson Plane Crash_ included personal accounts from passengers, rescuers, and witnesses.[49]
  * On February 21, 2009, [KGO-TV](/wiki/KGO-TV "KGO-TV") in San Francisco broadcast an interview in the "Face to Face" series. Dan Ashley talked to Captain and Mrs. Sullenberger about their experiences during and since the accident.[114]
  * On March 4, 2009, the [Discovery Channel](/wiki/Discovery_Channel "Discovery Channel") broadcast a one-hour documentary entitled _Hudson Plane Crash – What Really Happened_ , with [computer-generated imagery (CGI) animations](/wiki/Computer_animation "Computer animation") of the flight, and interviews with passengers, crew, witnesses, rescuers, and aviation safety experts.[115]
  * On January 10, 2010, [TLC](/wiki/TLC_\(TV_channel\) "TLC \(TV channel\)") aired a documentary entitled _Brace For Impact_ , aired again on April 14 in Australia as _Brace For Impact: Inside The Hudson Plane Crash_.[116]
  * In March 2011, [Ric Elias](/wiki/Ric_Elias "Ric Elias"), a front-row passenger shared his experience during a [TED conference](/wiki/TED_\(Conference\) "TED \(Conference\)").[117]
  * Beginning in June 2011, the [University of North Carolina](/wiki/University_of_North_Carolina_School_of_the_Arts "University of North Carolina School of the Arts") School of Filmmaking and Process Pictures, LLC worked with the Carolinas Aviation Museum to produce a documentary, which also looked at the impact of the incident on society.[118][119]

The crash was featured in the [Discovery Channel
(Canada)](/wiki/Discovery_Channel_\(Canada\) "Discovery Channel \(Canada\)") /
[National Geographic](/wiki/National_Geographic_Society "National Geographic
Society") TV series _[Mayday](/wiki/Mayday_\(Canadian_TV_series\) "Mayday
\(Canadian TV series\)")_ on the episode _[Hudson Splash
Down](/wiki/List_of_Mayday_episodes#Season_10_.282010.29 "List of Mayday
episodes")_.[120] It was also recreated in a [National Geographic
Channel](/wiki/National_Geographic_Channel "National Geographic Channel") TV
special titled "Miracle Landing on the Hudson,"[121] and in the United Kingdom
for a [Channel 5](/wiki/Channel_5_\(UK\) "Channel 5 \(UK\)") special in
2011.[122]

[Garrison Keillor](/wiki/Garrison_Keillor "Garrison Keillor") honored the
entire flight crew by writing a song and performing it on his show, _[A
Prairie Home Companion](/wiki/A_Prairie_Home_Companion "A Prairie Home
Companion")_.[123]

The ditching is referenced in the song "[A Real Hero](/wiki/A_Real_Hero "A
Real Hero")" by [College](/wiki/College_\(musical_project\) "College \(musical
project\)") and [Electric Youth](/wiki/Electric_Youth_\(band\) "Electric Youth
\(band\)"), best known from the 2011 movie _[Drive](/wiki/Drive_\(2011_film\)
"Drive \(2011 film\)")_. The lyrics of the second verse describe the water
landing and the survival of the passengers and crew, as well as alluding to
the freezing river.[124]

Sullenberger's memoir, _Highest Duty: My Search for What Really Matters_ was
adapted into a feature film _[Sully: Miracle on the
Hudson](/wiki/Sully_\(film\) "Sully \(film\)")_ , directed by [Clint
Eastwood](/wiki/Clint_Eastwood "Clint Eastwood"),[125] with [Tom
Hanks](/wiki/Tom_Hanks "Tom Hanks") as Sullenberger and [Aaron
Eckhart](/wiki/Aaron_Eckhart "Aaron Eckhart") as co-pilot Jeff Skiles.[126] It
was released by [Warner Bros.](/wiki/Warner_Bros. "Warner Bros.") on September
9, 2016.[127]

##
Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=US_Airways_Flight_1549&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Notes")]

  1. **Jump up ^** A serious injury is defined as any injury that (1) requires hospitalization for more than 48 hours, starting within seven days from the date that the injury was received; (2) results in a fracture of any bone, except simple fractures of fingers, toes, or the nose; (3) causes severe hemorrhages or nerve, muscle, or tendon damage; (4) involves any internal organ; or (5) involves second- or third-degree burns or any burns affecting more than 5 percent of the body surface. A minor injury is defined as any injury that does not qualify as a fatal or serious injury.[3]
  2. **Jump up ^** AWE1549, also designated under a [Star Alliance](/wiki/Star_Alliance "Star Alliance") [codeshare agreement](/wiki/Codeshare_agreement "Codeshare agreement") as _[United Airlines](/wiki/United_Airlines "United Airlines") Flight 1919_ UA1919.
  3. **Jump up ^** Delivered in 1999,[10] the plane, registered N106US, was one of 74 A320s then in service at US Airways. At the time of the accident its [airframe](/wiki/Airframe "Airframe") had logged 16,299 flights totaling 25,241 flight hours; and the engines 19,182 and 26,466 hours. The last "[A Check](/wiki/Aircraft_maintenance_checks#A_Check "Aircraft maintenance checks")" (performed every 550 flight hours) was passed on December 6, 2008, and the last [C Check](/wiki/C_check "C check") (annual comprehensive inspection) on April 19, 2008.[9][11]

  4. **Jump up ^** The engines are the primary source of electrical and hydraulic power for the [aircraft flight control systems](/wiki/Aircraft_flight_control_system "Aircraft flight control system"),[27] but an [auxiliary power unit](/wiki/Auxiliary_power_unit "Auxiliary power unit") (APU) can provide backup electrical power, and a [ram air turbine](/wiki/Ram_air_turbine "Ram air turbine") (RAT) can be deployed into the airstream to provide backup hydraulic pressure and electrical power at certain speeds.[27] Both the APU and RAT were operating as the plane descended onto the river.[27]
  5. **Jump up ^** The Airbus A320 has a control that closes valves and other openings in the [fuselage](/wiki/Fuselage "Fuselage"), in order to slow flooding after a water landing,[39] but the pilots did not activate it.[31] Sullenberger later said this would have made little difference since the water impact tore substantial holes in the fuselage.[17]
